message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vesiculopustular lesions on the back and sole of the foot, as well as the sexual activity and use of oral contraceptive, suggest a possible disseminated gonococcal infection. The joint symptoms and tenderness to palpation suggest arthritis. The other options do not fit the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of vesiculopustular rashes and sexual activity with one partner increases the likelihood of a sexually transmitted disease. The painful wrist and knee symptoms suggest arthritis. Among the options, Disseminated gonococcal infection is the most likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of sexual activity and use of oral contraceptives increases the likelihood of a sexually transmitted infection. The presence of vesiculopustular lesions and joint pain suggest a disseminated gonococcal infection. Reactive arthritis, acute rheumatic fever, and Staphylococcus aureus arthritis are less likely given the patient’s history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s sexual history and recent travel history combined with the presence of genital and skin lesions suggest a possible disseminated gonococcal infection, which can lead to arthritis symptoms. The other options are less likely given the patient’s history and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recent travel history and sexually active with one partner suggest that the most likely diagnosis is a disseminated gonococcal infection. The pain in the right knee and wrist, as well as the fever, supports this diagnosis. Reactive arthritis and acute rheumatic fever would require a history of streptococcal infection, which is not present in this case. Staphylococcus aureus arthritis typically presents with more localized symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recent travel, sexually active status and vesiculopustular lesions all point towards disseminated gonococcal infection as the most likely diagnosis. The knee swelling and extension of wrist and fingers may indicate septic arthritis. Reactive arthritis, Staphylococcus aureus arthritis, and acute rheumatic fever do not fit with the patient’s symptoms and history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recent sexual activity and the presence of vesiculopustular lesions suggest disseminated gonococcal infection. Swelling of the right knee with tenderness to palpation suggests arthritis. The other options do not fit the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest disseminated gonococcal infection, as it commonly presents with arthralgia and skin lesions. The history of sexual activity supports this diagnosis as well. Reactive arthritis and acute rheumatic fever usually have a history of streptococcal infection, while Staphylococcus aureus arthritis typically presents with a single joint involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recent travel to an area where Lyme disease is endemic (Connecticut), as well as symptoms of fever and pain in multiple joints. Along with the vesiculopustular lesions on the back and sole of the foot, these symptoms are indicative of disseminated gonococcal infection. Reactive arthritis and acute rheumatic fever are possible but less likely given the presentation, while Staphylococcus aureus arthritis would typically present with more localized joint pain and swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recent travel to Connecticut, sexually active with one partner, and vesiculopustular lesions suggest disseminated gonococcal infection, which can cause septic arthritis. Passive extension of the right wrist and fingers elicits pain, which is also a symptom of septic arthritis. Reactive arthritis and acute rheumatic fever are not associated with recent travel or sexual activity, and Staphylococcus aureus usually presents with a localized infection rather than disseminated infection.
